title: WSDC 2024 Serbia Round23   Croatia vs South Africa
motion: This House supports France's exit from West Africa.

argument_units.text: Okay. Last year, France made 17% of their GDP from colonial tax imposed on former colleagues, which is more than the GDP of Norway.
When France sends its army to protect people from terrorism, they end up only protecting French mines and factories.
To this day, France has ill intentions and it has to get out. In my speech, two arguments. First, about economy. Second, about the

development of ECOLAS. But before that, a few points of framing. What does France and West Africa look like? First, on the political level. It will cut ties but will still have diplomacy and consulates. On the economic level, trade deals, import and export can still exist. But French majority ownership of African national companies, particularly in raw resources, is no longer possible. Our alternative is to privatize, which implies the entry of foreign investors. The West's CFA franc must be dissolved as a currency. France's exit has to include exiting from Africa's monetary policy. On the military level, all French troops get withdrawn. What likely happens on our side is that West African countries have similar monetary needs. They're export-based economies and are already in an extensive trade union like ECOWAS. This likely means that these countries band together under the same currency as regulated by their own central bank.

First argument then about the economy. How is France damaging the West African economy? Primarily by imposing the CFA franc. It is a currency adopted by West African countries that is controlled by France. Printing, distribution, reserves. It is pegged to the euro under fixed exchange rate. There are two detrimental characteristics of it. First, the artificially high exchange rate. It favors imports to the detriment of exports because when countries with strong currencies would trade with the West African countries, they will gain money by switching currency, whereas when CFA fraud is pegged to the euro, a strong currency, other countries lose money by trading. The implication of this is when they have a lower exchange rate, they are a more attractive trading partner. On op, African countries cannot use their own currency as an instrument to boost price competitiveness. Second point, the reserves of West Africa are in France. Half of the money that West African countries have has to be in France. West African countries only have access to 20% of the revenue they generated in the prior year at any given time, which means that any project government wants to do has to be within the bounds of the revenue they generated in the prior year at any given time, which means that any project government wants to do has to be within the bounds of the budget. For example, when building an electrical grid, governments are unlikely to have the capital to upscale the grid to a size that would meet the demands of its most residents in the capital city, let alone areas around it. Furthermore, West African governments lose liquidity. Most money that they have is tied up in ongoing projects and government expenditure. Liquid money remains in France. This means governments have a much tougher time dealing with crisis situations or unforeseen expenses. Droughts, natural disaster, crises like COVID-19. Responses to these events are too slow and inadequate because France needs to determine whether the claim is legitimate and how much or when to transfer money. The impact of this, of both points, is seen in the example of Ivory Coast, the largest CFA franc country, whose GDP per capita is one-third lower than before the implementation of CFA franc. Our comparative here is that first, when West African countries don't have CFA franc, they can adjust their own currency to be more appropriate for international trade of raw resources. Secondly, West African countries get their own money directly. They get their half of GDP from reserves back, which means they have more money on hand. This means that West African countries now have the capacity to invest into things that people need. Agriculture, hospital, I'll take you later, manufacturing industries, water systems. This is especially important because none of West African citizens deserve a lower quality of life. They're stuck here due to birth lottery. Given that their lives are unbelievably difficult, fixing this injustice is a priority. Now a point. Do you support America's basic moral values? I don't see how this is relevant to this. I will just continue. I don't see how this is relevant to this. I will just continue. I don't see how this is relevant.

Second argument then about the development of ECOWAS. What is ECOWAS? This is an economic community of West African states. They have aspirations of trade liberalization and creating a common currency between member states. It is currently not very influential or active because of France. Because first, most of ECOWAS' goals are much easier to accomplish with a common currency, such as fair trade between nations. Secondly, ECOWAS member states are afraid of pivoting trade to each other. Right now, France is a big provider of local economic projects. Over 10% of Burkina Faso's foreign economic aid comes from France. They're afraid if they devote more resources to each other, France might backlash by pulling back support. This also creates a further disadvantage for initiating trade liberalization projects. Why is ECOWAS more active on crop? When France pays out, first, it presents opportunity to create common currency if CFA franc is gone. West African countries benefit from having a shared currency as it makes trade between each other easier. They will likely want one after the CFA franc is gone. West African countries benefit from having a shared currency as it makes trade between each other easier. They will likely want one after the CFA franc is dissolved. ECOWAS is the only body with the ability and political legitimacy to implement this. Note, the only reason these incentives don't manifest in the status quo is because of CFA franc's presence. Second point, how this creates export value. African countries are very likely to recognize the need to depend more on each other for trade. Because first, there is going to be an interim period before complex economic ties or deals are established, which can last for years. Economic growth and supply are still necessary then. Secondly, on suspicion. These countries are not likely to risk full trade and investment dependence on another foreign power again.

Voters are unlikely to believe dependence on any foreigners is reliable after historical presence like France leaves. How is this beneficial for West Africa? Two main reasons. First, economic reasons on a

bargaining power. Like any large economic union, big trade deals are likely to be mediated through the union rather than individual countries. Common resources like oil, uranium, or cocoa will likely be pooled between these nations and bargained with as a group. Grouping resources gives West Africa control over the majority of a certain product on the market, giving them bargaining power and control over pricing. More money for products sold means more money to the individual countries. This is very important that these are export-based nations, which will bring a significant boost to the GDP then. B, uncirculation of capital. Instead of consumers' money going into the developed world, it gets spent on African products and African industries staying in West Africa. Second point about security reasons. ECOWAS also functions as a military union of all involved nations. It pulls military power from West Africa and either directly involves itself in conflict or gives armed support to countries which need it. In the status quo, its security function isn't relevant because it is insufficiently funded and lacks authority. Note how our argument mechanizes why this changes. ECOWAS would be more successful in perpetuating African stability through fighting back internal insurgencies and terrorists in member states. Important examples of when ECOWAS was more influential and succeeded in this is when ECOWAS led the office mission in 2013 to destroy an almost successful coup attempt on Mali. ECOWAS would also be more successful in fighting back against terrorist forces than individual French or Chinese military bases in West Africa. ECOWAS would have insights into connected terrorist cells between countries, access to military generals who have been active in the region since Islamic terror or insurgency groups rose. This is the exclusive benefit of ECOWAS, incentive and capacity for all involved countries to share security info. On top, African militaries can outsource responsibility to the French military as it is perceived as the most legitimate military in the area. They do this due to scarce resources that need to be allocated elsewhere. Overall, if ECOWAS was given an opportunity to grow, first, African economies would grow alongside it. Secondly, through creation and growing legitimacy of ECOWAS, African states would be far more likely to reduce tensions and de-escalate wars between each other. And thirdly, African states would be significantly more successful in fighting back of terrorists and insurgents. Both sides here aspire to give Africa a better future. Only on our side we can show you how we do this. So I beg you to propose. Thank you. How's that? How's that? How's that?

Because, panel, this is a this-house-support motion, i.e. they have to defend how France has existed in status quo. We told you often they're willing to do the stuff that younger people aren't, and they take on important, valuable jobs in local government. So because we preserve voter choice and because we benefit from experience as well as youth, we are so proud to oppose.

A team in England claims that Biden never got the post when he was 20. It was because of the monopoly that was already created by the older politicians that prevented him from getting this post in power.

Side opposition restricts choice to individuals who have already monopolized the political systems. We give you three reasons as to why they restrict politics to the older generation. One, we tell you that the monopoly of politics due to the power that is already accumulated with the massive money that these individuals have. Secondly, we tell you that in many countries, things like corruption exist. Countries like Uganda, even if it is a democracy, we tell you that corruption exists and rigging of votes exists. But also finally, we tell you things like arresting of political opponents exists. And this is a clear characterization that comes in in

past speech which they don't engage. The responses that they give us are twofold. One, they tell us that they give choice to individuals, but we tell you two major things. One, it is not choice when individuals are coerced to voting people who already have high places in power. It is not subtle choice. But also secondly, Jesse tells you specifically in his speech, if choice is important, why don't we give children that choice to participate within these elections? Secondly, they tell us that they have checks and balances existing within their side of the house. This is still mitigated from our first speech, our second speech, and third speech, when we tell you that things like corruption literally exist within these countries. They don't give us any responses as to why this is not true. They cannot take it at that point.

We tell you that is why, even if younger people don't want older people within power because of them not being able to make sentences, they still put them into power because of them being able to rig or manipulate these political systems. They cannot take this debate at that stance. Secondly, they give us something to do with older people having an incentive to benefit the society. What do we tell you on this sort of idea? We tell you that one, all of us live in the society, we experience the bad things that happen within these societies, that gives us an incentive to work on those societies. But we still tell you that the specific thing about younger individuals is that they have a longer term stay within the society. That means that they would want to benefit the society more. And this specifically comes in my speech and Zephyr's speech, which is something that is not tackled by their side of the house.

But also, secondly, we're still telling that on our side of the house, if individuals can be involved in political systems, that is to say, their policies can still be passed on to younger individuals, and they can still self-actualize at that instance, they don't respond to that, they cannot take this today. That means, they tell us that older individuals can still feel neglected and polarized within the society. We think that the same push that they had with saying that the state has an incentive to protect younger people is the same push that we still have on our side of the house to say that the state will still want to protect these older individuals. We think that this is something that is rather symmetric. It cannot exist within this debate.

Finally, they give us something to do with their experience and how these individuals have some sort of experience. We think that this was something that was first engaged in framing. When we tell you that this is a merit-based process, that means that we're not going to get each and every individual just run for office. But also, secondly, we show how majority of the major politicians start when they are young, and they get that level of experience from there. We think that that is something that cannot stand

within this debate. What do we tell you from our speeches today? One, we tell you that we get more younger individuals within the political process and that is something that is good. Why? We tell you this is under two circumstances. One, they can exercise politics because we break the monopoly. That means they can engage fairly and they go against each other. But also secondly, they can get to vote because of the better optics that exist. We don't get any response as to why we actually don't have as to the voter turn up on our side of the house. Notice that this is an argument that exists from the first speech which is not responded to. That means that they cannot take this vote. Also secondly, we're telling that many leaders, 60 and above, still have problems to think. They have cognitive disabilities. That is to say, 53% of them have these disabilities. We think that they do not clearly handle this. They cannot take it. Our case was never that there are no good leaders who are 65 years and above. But our case was they have problems that infringe on their working, which we need to solve with the younger generation being able to engage within politics. We take this debate from the side. Thank you.

title: WSDC 2024 Serbia Double Octofinals New Zealand vs Scotland
motion: This House would put an upper age limit of 60 years old for individuals running for political office.

argument_units.text: Best of luck to both teams. I now hand over the floor to our chair judge Thank you. Panel, in South Korea, we put an upper age limit of 55 years on all pilots because the risk of potentially failing mid-flight could lead to hundreds of deaths.
When you are the president of a nation of hundreds of millions of individuals, this risk is so much worse. I'm very

proud to propose. I'm going to do three things in this speech. First, why does the status quo heavily favor old people? Secondly, why old politicians pose a political risk? And then secondly, why elderly politicians harm political discourse? On the status quo then, the first thing I want to

talk about is about how politicians get selected in the first place. Firstly, on candidate selection, usually this happens in two ways. A, when party leaders or committees decide, this looks like in the UK or New Zealand, party leaders tend to be disproportionately old, because first, the longer you've been in politics, the more clout you tend to have and the more reputation you tend to have. But secondly, you often have to be rewarded or be seen to be rewarded for your past service. This looks like how the Australian Labour Party will almost always pick Peter Dutton as their leader, or how Winston Peters will always be the New Zealand first leader in our country. No, older people are more likely to be comfortable with other older people, and this is very unfair to the young individuals. But sec B, on primary systems like in the United States, old candidates are still likely to be the ones selected because primary voters are disproportionately old because first, voting in primaries is a very high investment process because you have to pay to be a registered member of the party, but you also have to spend a lot of time to physically go to the party headquarters

and stand around for hours to vote for your party leader. But secondly, old individuals are often single-issue voters, like concerns about pensions that are very proximate to you as an individual. And they're extremely motivated to come out and support other older individuals. But second layer, then, on the actual elections, why are old people still heavily favoured? First, they have the narrative of having experience, like not shaking the ship. And so the lack of experience will always be used to attack younger politicians, even if this isn't true. Like in 2008, Obama was heavily attacked for being too young, even though he had been a senator previously. So this is often a vicious cycle because all parties feel the need to do this. But secondly, there's often very strong name recognition for older politicians because they've been there for a lot, like, certainly in voting patterns, the most reliable block of voters are often old individuals because they have a lot of free time, because they're very motivated, because they tend to be quite wealthy and have the capacity to spend a long time in line. So why do old individuals still get represented on the outside of the house? First, we're not taking away their right to vote, and so there's still a very large electoral block. But secondly, there's still a very reliable voting base, right? So the issue in the status quo is not the old people in and of themselves, but there's far too many old individuals in power. What this means then is that on our side, we're able to cater more to young people. So why do old

politicians pose a political risk? The first layer to this point is the potential risk of mental incompetency, because why does being in office link to mental deterioration? Four reasons. First, there's extremely high stress, so you're responsible for an entire country of individuals or in charge of a particular ministry in your country, for example. And this puts an exorbitant amount of pressure on you as an individual. But secondly, there's a very high intellectual burden to being a politician. It's because you have to deal with very complex legal frameworks, international relationships, for example. It's a very high skill than the average job but third it's very emotionally draining because everyone hates you as a politician at least half the country probably does so you're always personally attacked for your failures policies but fourth it's very physically exhausting right this is because you have to spend a lot of hours traveling or speaking at conferences and it's just been some very long hours right so it's for example during preparation for the debate, Joe Biden spent about 15 hours a day sleeping from 8 to 11, right? It's very incredibly physically tiring on you as an individual. Why is this particularly exacerbated for old people? First, they've already deteriorated to a very large extent. They're just slower as individuals, they tire more quickly, and they take longer to make more decisions. But their metabolism is also just incredibly slow, right? But secondly, there's increased stress factors having a multiplied effect. Because if you try to run... So maybe they try to run a counter-model on political competency, but in many instances, they're actually fine when they enter office, but these extreme amounts of stress that put you in pressure actually make you even worse as you go along. So even if you do run a comparative of like political competency tests, they're not likely to work. Second layer then is how there is a lack of internal accountability within these parties. Because no one challenges these older politicians. Because firstly, there is a perception that they are more electable for stability. Because these internal politicians, as we've proved to you in set up, often have a lot of status quo bias. But secondly, in many cases, these politicians are the ones who gave you a job in the first place. If they don't want to challenge you because they either feel a debt to you or they don't want to lose their job, this looks like how Mitch McConnell will always be the leader of GOP, or at least for a very long time. That's why it's unlikely to change. What are the outcomes at this point, then? At the lowest level, there's a very big time trade-off to having very old politicians in party. This is because it takes longer to file a report draft or a bill, but you spend less time doing your job overall because you need to spend more time napping just because you're older, right? This is very reasonable because you spend a lot of time doing other things like caring for your health. This looks like needing to go see a Parkinson's expert, for example, because you're worried about your health. Also, more of your job is just delegated auto-advisors or bureaucrats. No, this is a principal harm to democracy, because if your elected official is not the one actually doing the job and representing you, it's very harmful on that front, right? But on the higher level, you're just more likely to make mistakes in general. It's almost like calling Zelensky Putin by accident. But no, this can often be far more pernicious and far more destructive when you are in charge of the country's nuclear program, but no, this can often be far more pernicious and far more destructive when you are in charge of the country's nuclear program, for example, because the stakes are really high when you have to deal with international presidents in the stage. But third, you can often be removed from politics because of your age, either because you literally die or you get incredibly sick or you just get removed by the rest of your party. And this is a huge disaster for politics because there's an extreme disruption to the political process because it now holds policy and it holds decision making when you now need to spend a lot of time selecting a new politician. And now the person elected isn't always a person who's in power, which means people often feel far more disenfranchised by the state. Before I move on, I'll take a point. Let's trust-crash the UK economy. Why does youth automatically mean

Jewish politicians? Look, we don't think youth automatically means good politicians, but we explain to you why when you're older, you're more likely to be infringed in your systems. So if Liz Truss were older, it would be far more difficult for her to be removed from her position. So, why do elderly politicians harm political
discourse then? Note then four reasons. First, age

is the lowest hanging fruit to critique, because it's very visible and easy to criticise in any manner instead of your political stance, right? So, A, it becomes a huge media issue. For example, Dianne Feinstein's stroke in the Senate. But B, it's often weaponised by your opposition, like Donald Trump always calling Joe Biden Sleepy Joe. But C, you have to spend a lot of time defending your own age. And this looks like how the Democrat Party puts up interviews just to make Joe Biden seem more youthful. This is a huge cost for your party. This has two harms. First, you crowd out more relevant political discussion because it's far more interesting and scandalous to just talk about your politician's age. But secondly, you waste a lot of time doing interviews and spending a lot of money trying to prove your youth that could be used instead to prove your policies. So secondly then, young people who are already less likely to vote as they don't have established voting patterns often view these politics as less proximate to them because of politicians' age. So when you see Joe Biden tripping over his feet on stage and trailing off mid-sentence, you probably don't think he's going to pass legislation that will help you. But even if they appear competent, you're still unlikely to relate to their policy platform. This looks like how Winston Peters only talks about retirement age in New Zealand. But third, we often get less new candidates when people stay in politics for a very long time. This means that A, you're more likely to vote for familiar faces, but B, there's less challenges because you don't think you're likely to win. This is very bad because new candidates often need to generate a lot of discussion about their policies because they have no other opportunity. What this means then is that, on the comparative, they're more likely to care about individual policies. What this means then is that, firstly, there are going to be more young individuals caring about politics in the first place. But secondly, the campaigns are actually focused on what actually matters in politics, insofar as democracy is about policies that help individuals I'm very proud to be here. Okay, can everyone hear me if I speak at this volume?
A political landscape without fair representation is coercion. We cannot stand for a world where people are left without their free choices. We oppose.
A couple of points are set up, then the motto will be integrated throughout.

Firstly, on our stance. We want to note that anyone with capacity can stand for election. We are fine with enforcing things like the age of legality, saying that only people who are over 18 or 21, depending on the laws of the nation, are able to stand, because they are unable to fill their obligations otherwise. We are also willing to support things like a capacity test to test whether politicians are truly in control of their senses and able to enact the offices in the correct manner. Notice, they try to tell us that we cannot have this if it is ineffective. I'd like to respond to that here. Our capacity tests are effective because we can do them on a regular basis. That is to say, they can be done with every yearly health check-up, meaning we are able to test when someone's cognitive ability has declined since they have been in office. They try to tell you that removing them from office is this terrifying thing. It really isn't, panel. We have a variety of methods in place for us to be able to remove politicians who are failing to meet their obligations. We have vice presidents or vice prime ministers who are able to step up in these cases. But I want a response to a few other things they try to tell you. They tell you that the nature of being a politician is inherently challenging and that leads to cognitive decline. To the extent that this is a challenging job, we think the impact that it has on people is limited insofar as they fail to meet their burden here. They are telling you exclusively about Biden, a literal 81-year-old. They are not talking to you about over 60-year-olds. The people in this round that you have to care about, that they have to justify, is limiting the ability of these people who are 61, not just those who are over 80. But what we think here is crucially, Biden literally steps down because of his age. I don't know whether this news is filtered down to the New Zealand bench yet, but they literally had to remove Biden because his age was becoming so problematic. That is to say, there already exist mechanisms for us to prevent people whose cognitive ability is in such serious decline from standing for election we don't think that their model actually solves this okay let's look
at a second point of our stance then on what countries are talking about we obviously believe

we're talking here about free democracies where people have alternatives to choose first argument then on democratic principled rights and how we are the side that fulfills them the thesis of this claim is that the state has significant power over your life and only by allowing for you to have control over the way in which you work at worst can this free democracy and this control of the state be justified. Why then does this right exist? We are born under the control of the state having never accepted that coercion. We have never consented to being part of the state. It is simply something we are born into. That justifies an unconstitutional imposition on our freedoms. The state owes you in return some freedom back, and the way it gives that to you is through voting, and crucially, through the ability to stand for office. They try to tell you that voting is sufficient here. That simply is not, because when you are voting, you have to be able to choose whether you are someone who could represent your preferences greater and to a better extent than any of the candidates who are currently being fielded. They limit the democratic principled rights in two ways here. One, on removing the right to stand. Voting does not guarantee that there is someone who represents your preferences who could take your position in Parliament. We think that only by allowing someone to stand can we actually enable them to access their preferences. That is to say that if I do not see anyone in the political landscape who is advocating for what I want, I ought to be able to stand up and say, well, I'll do it then. I will stand up for this person. They have to explain why they are willing to remove this ability to influence politics from these people. But two, they remove the ability for people to vote freely. Let's note the previous mechanism I've given to you applies to people over the age of 60 whose proposition limits them standing. But the second mechanism applies to literally everyone who votes in free democracies. That is to say you ought to be able to choose who best aligns with your preferences. Whether I, as an 18-year-old, choose that that person is a 76-year-old or a 25-year-old, it doesn't matter. What matters is I ought to be able to make that decision for myself. If I believe that Biden's age is an issue, I ought to be able to, as literally happened, advocate for the Democratic Party to push him out. This affects everyone in democracy. They cannot outweigh this harm. The only two cases in which we are willing to infringe upon these rights in our society is if you are, A, a minor, that is to say you cannot enact the ability of the state's office because you do not have full rights under the law, or B, you lack literal capacity, that is to say if you are literally imprisoned, you cannot run for office because you cannot be president from a jail cell. Those are the only two times when it is fair to justify these impositions. Propositions don't stand for this. But I want to weigh this principle then. The beliefs of individual people should be ultimately respected by a state which has coerced them into every choice in their life. That is to say, because we live in a world in which we have no alternative to the state that governs us, we have to be able to control the ways in which we are imposed upon. If we are unable to do this through voting and through standing in a free manner, we are imposed upon. If we are unable to do this, through voting and through standing in a free manner, we are just unable to get anything other than a coercive system. We respect choice of utility at every step of our principle of obligations. That is to say, it would be completely unjustified for us to tie someone down and inject them with dopamine, even if that was an enjoyable experience for them. We limit their ability to choose the things which they are accessing. Therefore, even if Proposition choose, these people would be better politicians. What matters here is choice. Before I move on to my second argument, I'll take a point. So if your principle is fairness in democracy, why is it fair that a majority of politicians are over the age of 50 when there is a minority of people in society? I'm going to explain in my second argument why they are the side which actually limits the number of people who are able to go into politics from alternative backgrounds. Second argument then, on the benefit of having people with life experiences in politics. The thesis of this claim is that only on opposition are we able to get people from different backgrounds, different career experiences, and different life-lived experiences in politics, creating a political landscape which is more varied and enjoyable for the people who engage in it. Two ways in which this is true.

Firstly, on getting people in politics who have access to valuable life experiences. Notice, the trend of politicians increasingly coming from older age categories is driven by people having previous careers before they went into politics. That is to

say, people who were doctors and became so disenfranchised with their government's health system that they went into politics to try to advocate for change. That is why we see older politicians under the status quo. Having access to these lived experiences means we break the political bubble which encourages people to just live in the echo chamber of Westminster or the Capitol Hill. We think only by allowing people to have lived experiences are we able to actually enact the changes that people need in their day-to-day lives. We think that when you have lived experiences, you have more knowledge on the impact that you're able to make in policy. But look, this is exclusive. They might try to tell you that people are still able to have careers before they go into politics, but this is not true. If you were to have a meaningful career as a lawyer or a teacher or a doctor, you have to dedicate 20, 30, 40 years to this career. Even if they get people going into politics after having been an accountant for five years, they just have had to sacrifice a great amount of live-life experiences to get to that point and are never able to actually access the knowledge which would enable them to make the policy decisions which are the most successful but additionally here even if you have had a career that lasts for 20 plus years why are you unlikely to go into politics on their side two reasons here one on the limited benefits if you are 50 you know that seeking re-election is not worth it for you because at maximum you're going to get what two electoral cycles in politics that just isn't enough for you to be able to make the mark you would wish to but two you know that you're just unlikely to get what two electoral cycles in politics and it just isn't enough for you to be able to make the mark you would wish to. But two, you know that you're just unlikely to succeed. That is to say it often takes people a long time as they concede to work up their way in the political system, to get the name recognition, to get the notions, to get the support in order to be able to actually access politics. They lock people out of doing this by ensuring that only career politicians are able to rise up, not those who have any actual lived experiences. But two, on access for different people. When you are young, under their side, and you know you have to enter politics at this age, this means you have to come from a particular background. You need money to enter into politics for three reasons. One, you need to be able to donate to your campaign to fund it. Two, you need to have living costs for yourself to be able to survive during that campaign. And three, you need to come from a privileged background to have the connections you need to succeed. Do you know what this means it means that on their side no young people are ever able to rise up because they are just unable to get the knowledge and the know-how that they need in order to access the money and the funding and the name recognition to actually succeed in politics this is us flipping their point on youth representation because we tell you you're unable to get youth in politics when they know that they are unable to do the things which are a prerequisite to them being able to access success. The only way that working class politicians were able to rise up is because they had time to gain money and a reputation. That is to say, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders were able to do things before they went into politics. That's how they were able to maintain their progressive ideology. The impacts of this are twofold. One, we get more varied politics which gives better choices for the individuals who we're engaging with. That means we have more people, say, from science backgrounds than just those from social subjects. But two, we just get greater voter engagement. That is to say, people who see they have more choices and are more willing to engage. Young people who see that young people are able to enter into it are just more willing to engage. Under their side, the alternative is career politicians, people with no experience, people who come from a privileged background, because we are the side that stands for true democracy and true representation we are so proud to oppose. Thank you. All right. Thank you. The problem with Ops' claim that the only way to get people from minority and underprivileged backgrounds into politics is when they are old

is that it doesn't engage with all of the reasons that we gave you at Bruce as to why people with privilege are always empowered, are always put above those without it. That is why even when you have the ability to have old people in politics there just simply isn't that representation of minorities that you talk about. The way that we do get that representation is by making room for more young voters. We already told you about why that was important but also to note that the fact is young voters are the ones that are much more likely to be voting people in from underprivileged backgrounds anyway.

Because they're the ones who care more about progressive policy, because they're the ones who are more likely to understand that it is important to have representation of minority issues in politics, that's why that is the way that we get more diversity.

I have a few things I want to talk about in this speech. Firstly, dealing with their principle and clashing it with our material on how we get better political discourse. Secondly then, the capacity of these old people in politics. And thirdly, just dealing with this material on life experience. So what do they say in their principle?

It's important that we have the right for anybody to stand. It is unclear then why they support the age of legality and not this restriction that we are putting on people. Because the age of legality is in place because it says that somebody is incapable of running, somebody doesn't have the mental capacity to run when they are too young. Why then do you think it is okay for people to run when they're over the age of 60? We already told you all reasons as to why their mental deterioration happens, as to why it particularly happens when these people are in office. That was never engaged with. You need to deal with that

material. But their whole mechanism is just that anyone can run and that that is important. We gave you structural reasons as to why older politicians are structurally locked into power anyway. The fact that, one, their reputation is compounding. Secondly, the old voting bias. And thirdly, the fact that youth are easily attacked for being incapable of working in politics. That means young people are the ones locked out of democracy in the status quo,

not old people. That is the principle that you should care about. The other layer to the principle is that you should be able to choose as a voter who you vote for. I have two major responses here. Firstly, it doesn't engage with our second point around making an informed decision. We think as a voter, it is not important for you to just turn up and decide who you want to vote for. Look, if somebody turned up to the voting booth and knew nothing about any of the candidates, do you really think their right to choose which name they think sounds the best is important here? I think what's most important is that they make an informed decision based on knowing things about these politicians.

We explained why the discourse that happens under their side of the house means that you cloud out the actual important things about these people's policy. The fact that age is the lowest hanging fruit to critique because, A, it becomes a huge media issue, but B, it's weaponized by the opposition. C, you have to spend a lot of time defending your age to your party constituents, critique because a it becomes a huge media issue but b it's weaponized by your opposition c you have to spend a lot of time defending your age to your party constituents which means you can't spend that time on talking about your policy but d also just that's what becomes the thing that people talk about it is much easier for you there is much lower barrier of entry you feel like you're able to discuss that joe biden shouldn't be in politics because of his age instead of talking about the policy that just means you just get a less informed populist voting. We cannot stand by that, because that is the thing that undermines the principal harms of democracy. But the second thing I want to say here is that young people already aren't able to choose who they vote for. They're already not engaging in that right to choose in the status quo. We told you young people are disengaged from politics. There are four reasons for this. Firstly, because they don't have already established voting patterns that they can just rely on to vote in a particular way. But secondly, because they have other concerns they view as more proximate, since politicians don't cater to them. This doesn't mean that the things that politicians are doing aren't relevant to them. They are talking about education. They are talking about climate change. But, you know, they're not framing that as the main thing that they are pushing, but it's things that they're doing behind the scenes. We think these are things that young voters do care about, because they're not framed in the main frame of mind of what these politicians are campaigning for. They get disengaged. But thirdly, because young people aren't taught enough about politics and voting processes in schools, it makes them disengage from these systems. But fourthly, we already gave you reasons as to why they're undermined for being young. This looks like not being listened to in family discussions. It looks like being told that your ideas are naive. They internalise this feeling of incompetence and feel like there's no point in me going out to vote. These are the people that are disengaged from the status quo. These are the people that undermine the principle that everyone should have the right to choose who gets put in power. And these are the people that we make room for on our side of the house. Look, the impact of more young voter turnout is not just that we get a better fulfillment of this principle of democracy. It is clear that the reason why the principle of democracy exists is to ensure the best utilitarian outcomes for everyone in the population. This is why we get things like more progressive policy when we get more young voters in because that is what young voters care about. There is a reason why politicians are able to just undermine climate change and throw those issues under the rug because old people don't care as much because they're not having to live into the future generations that are going to have to deal with its effects. It looks like old women in politics not caring about abortion rights because they're not the ones who are going to need to have abortions in the future because they're already too old. We think the comparative is when you have discourse around policy. This is incredibly important because this is what mobilizes voters. We think that insulting somebody based on their traits, based on their age, is not the kind of thing that will incentivize a person to skip a day of work, to wait hours in line to go out and vote. The only thing that will be able to do that is when you talk about policy, when you talk about

the things that people actually care about. Maybe Trump calls Kamala a virtue signaller, but if he can point to Biden stuttering and stumbling, that's what does incentivize Democrats from voting, and that's what undermines democratic principles.

Then they, on our material, next, on the capacity of these people in Parliament. The only thing they say is that we'll have a regular basis of capacity tests. Firstly, it is to say that there are degrees of deterioration. One slip-up can be really harmful for your politics. You know, when Joe Biden calls the president of Ukraine Putin, that's really bad and turns away a lot of voters. We don't think that's the kind of thing that would signal you as unfit for politics in these capacity tests. Just because you're taking a bit longer time to do things doesn't mean you're necessarily going to be flagged as unfit for politics, but it does mean that the things that you are doing in politics aren't as good as they should be. It does mean that you're taking a longer time to push through important policy. But secondly, we explained why there is a problem with removing people from power when these capacity tests claim that they are now unfit. Because A, it disrupts policy and systems in the interim when you have to find a new person, when that person can no longer go to the meetings. But B, because it is principally undemocratic, when the person that was elected into power is now removed and somebody else stands in that was never voted in. But C, because you get a lack of public trust in the system when you are showing that, look, we have put somebody into power who is now unfit, it's much better that we enforce the restriction before that person ever gets into power in the first place so we remove this kind of lack of public trust that leads to voter disengagement. title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY04 Round21   Hong Kong vs England
motion: This House supports France's exit from West Africa.

argument_units.text: Many wonder why the citizens of Niger wave the Russian flag after the 2023 coup, why China is seen as a lifeline despite its alleged debt-trap diplomacy.
The reality is, when you speak to those in Burkina Faso and West Africa, those who are plagued by extremist violence despite France's military presence, you understand why.
A country can do good things in some places, yet awful things

elsewhere. While China and Russia are often demonized in the West, they're a necessary evil in West Africa. What do we support? A, the removal of French troops from all of West Africa. Recently, France has withdrawn its troops from Operation Barcane from Mali in 2021, was forced to leave Burkina Faso in 2023, and was kicked out of Niger at the end of 2023. Paris has also indicated plans to withdraw its troops from Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire, and Gabon. These comprise all the countries France has exited within West Africa. B. French companies divesting from West Africa. This looks like the Bolloré Group, run by a politically influential French billionaire, selling their 42 ports in the region. There are already discussions of the sale of French assets with companies like the Swiss-Italian MSC, the Danish Maersk, as well as Chinese and Indian companies. Let's be clear about what the opposition must support. France's exit is not an abstract proposal. It occurred through France being expelled from Niger, Burkina Faso, and Mali. Opposition cannot create a hypothetical world where there were no coups, there weren't mass violent protests, and colonial resentment did not exist. They must give a reasonable explanation of how France would have stayed in power to prove their comparative. Are they in support of using French forces to oust the military in Burkina Faso at a risk of a major war? Would they have remained in Niger even when the junta threatened not to let food or supplies cross the territory and reach French military bases? Would they have suppressed the protests outside French embassies late last year? We need an answer.

First argument, then, on why France's exit improves West Africa's security. The Sahel is in a crisis. Empirically, France has failed to provide West Africa with the security it required, particularly in the battle against jihadist groups. This looks like the terror groups murdering 45,000 in Mali, 8,000 in Niger, 10,000 in Burkina Faso. In Jibo, Burkina Faso, JNIM killed anybody who tried to leave the town, raided the cattle, and left those living there to starve to death. When France left, Russia sent in servicemen through the Wagner Group, now known as the Afrika Korps and the Ministry of Defense, liberating large swaths of Burkina Faso over four months. Why is Russia a better security partner than France? Before that, yes. Russia uses Mali as a training ground for working forces. France is in these countries fulfilling a specific mandate to end terrorism. Who's better protected to be on the ground? This argument will answer that. Why is Russia a better security partner than France? What matters are the incentives and capacity of actors in meeting their goals. While France, like Russia, may have incentives to provide security to gain allies and access to resources, they are constrained by disincentives. This answers their POI. First, the French government primarily cares about its domestic success. Thus, it's unlikely to take the risks needed to protect those in Mali or Burkina Faso. It is incredibly unpopular to lose troops abroad. When 39 French troops were killed in Mali in 2019, the story was sensationalized in every French newspaper. At best, France attempts to protect major areas controlled by French companies. Russia is less casualty-averse than France. That's because Russia is not a democracy. It doesn't have a free media, so Putin doesn't need to care about the sensationalization of the deaths of a few soldiers. This means that Russian ground troops can be placed strategically to root out jihadists, destroy their bases, and seize their weapons. Russia is willing to redirect Wagner to West Africa, which keeps them far away and prevents the chance of another coup attempt, repeating last summer. Second, France refuses to sell offensive weaponry in West Africa, as it wants them to maintain their reliance on French forces for defense. Without offensive weaponry, West African states aren't able to push back insurgent groups, and instead, insurgencies gain the ability to regroup and prepare for another attack. Russia and China are far more willing to sell military offensive weaponry. To gain influence, Russia has differentiated itself from France by granting more independence to them, which they can independently use to more effectively root out jihadists. And although they may not gain total control, this is what gives them the ability to gain some control. Russia's capacity to sell weapons is not limited by the Ukrainian war. The weapons that you need to fight a Western-funded army in Ukraine are hugely different from what you need to fight jihadists. These weapons may be old by Russian standards, but are more than sufficient to defeat poorly equipped jihadist groups with outdated weaponry. This is why Russia's Ministry of Defense sold old MiG-29 fighters to the army, Verba surface-to-surface missiles, and T-54 tanks to Burkina Faso. Thus, we guarantee security, saving lives, and creating the preconditions for investment, as stability for investors is secured.

Second argument, on why France's dominance uniquely exploits West Africa. All countries, be it the US, China, or Russia, act primarily in their own interests. Modern France's actions in West Africa are no exception. Those interests are exploitative. Why? First, France wants to maximize benefits for its voters. These are cheaper products imported from West Africa, a secure supply of uranium from Niger, and a captive consumer base. In contrast, the daily details of French exploitation in West African politics are of little interest to most French voters. Second, the 200 French MNCs in West Africa want the best deals possible. Companies like the oil giant Total or Orano Nuclear Group. These companies are major employers, control 75% of the regional oil giant Total or Orano Nuclear Group. These companies are major employers, control 75% of the regional oil trade, and have huge political power. Total Energy is notorious for hiring veteran diplomats and policymakers like Macron's former chief of staff, Ismail Emelian. Powerful French officials know that their most lucrative exit option are into the private sectors of these French MNCs, and thus will push for their interests. How does France exert their control? France is a new colonial power in much of West Africa. It uses that power to limit the ability of other countries to challenge it or control contracts and vital resources. First, France holds control over many West African governments. It does so through hand-picking the rulers and members of the elite, or providing support for their political cronies even when they grossly abused human rights. For instance, Omar Bongo was promoted from a minor politician to a president via a French-supported coup, before ruling Gabon as a brutal dictator for over 40 years. There are similar stories in Chad and Cameroon. Second, France acts as a key intermediary between West African states and others. This is through Bolloré, a company that owns 42 ports in the region and has historically forwarded French interests, like prioritizing French companies to the exclusion of other nations, which import into and export out of West Africa. Why is the alternative far better? When West African states are freed from French control, they can negotiate with a range of different partners. There are numerous countries which want to conclude new trade deals, invest, or make a play for military contracts following French withdrawal. As a result of increased options, West African countries now operate as kingmakers, choosing which countries to partner with. You can now garner new investment from countries like Russia, China, and Turkey to get the best terms and deals. Russia and Chinese influence may increase, but neither will ever hold the exclusionary influence that France had. France had control over the ports, the currency, the political system, and was the region's dominant security partner. Russia may have some power in the security realm, but China has never sent significant troops to fight abroad, so cannot act as a security guarantor. No country can purchase all of the 42 ports, but China and EU countries are likely to buy at least some. China and Russia's interests are not just in West Africa. They are positioning themselves as alternatives to the West to attract allies and secure markets globally. Russia needs new trade partners given Western sanctions. China is concerned about an increasingly aggressive America and wants to secure support and markets. Thus, both are seriously concerned about their image in states that are not closely aligned with the West. One of their main selling points is that they are not the people that oppressed you. If they act overly maliciously, they risk losing allies all around the world. This is reflected in how China, which a decade ago seized ports, now cares about its international reputation and has participated in Western debt restructuring in Zambia, Ghana, and Sri Lanka. Thus, we increase West Africa's options and economic partners, improving their ability to make deals and generate millions in revenue. Thank you. In 2013, Mali begged France to intervene as the Malian army was overwhelmed by an Islamic

fundamentalist caliphate which had control of most of its territory. Only France had the resources and the will to fight for Malian sovereignty and this is still true today. Side proposition doesn't want to talk to you about why France was there in the first place. Because freedom does not mean the freedom to become Afghanistan, Iraq, or Libya re-opposed.

title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY03 Round14    England vs Singapore

title: WSDC 2024 R7 - Japan vs Nepal
description:
This House supports France's exit from West Africa.

2-1 Nepal Wins
motion: This House supports France's exit from West Africa.

argument_units.text: It is merely a myth that colonialism is a relic of the past. France continues to exploit and steal from the pockets of West African citizens, forcing them to work below minimum wage. Pre-colonial French tendencies continue to suck up uranium in Niger and plunder crude oil in Gabon.

It pulls the strings of West African politics through overthrowing democratically elected leaders, orchestrating coups, and paying bribes in favour of pro-French leaders like Ali Gawang in exchange for control and natural resources. On Team Japan, we say it is time to tell them that we are no longer

going to tolerate this exploitation. We are extremely proud of those. A few points on set-up before we finish up three arguments. First, on principle. Secondly, on how we get economic development, thirdly on how we get regional stability in the region. A few points on set up. What does the French exit look like and what is the French exit? France's exit from West Africa is a combination of military exit, political exit and economic exit that has occurred since Macron's admissions office in 2017. This is independence, this is kicking out French corporations. This is removing the French military. What is the comparative then? In Proposition's world, after the French exit, we think that power over politics, the economy, and the military falls into the hands of local governments who actually affect citizens' interests. This is factually true, but what are the structural reasons for this? Firstly, West African citizens value democracy above anything else, driven by generational trauma from colonial rule and a strong desire for autonomy and dignity following their recent independence. Look how 67% of West Africans say they prefer democracy over any type of rule. Secondly, but even in countries with weaker democracies, they are likely to transition to civilian rule because a general general international pressure, b. ECOWAS military interventions, all military juntas in West Africa have set up plans to transition to civilian rules in the next five years, c. when one country democratizes, it opens up its democratic media and imposes a trickling which can force other countries to transition into civilian rule as well. What do we support on our side then? Firstly, we still support trade with other countries including France, but secondly, what we do not support on our side is the military presence of France and countries having governments avoided by France. Two arguments from the proposition then,
but for that I'll take your view on it. If it is so true that people know what they want, why is there an increase in the number of of military juntas who always claim that they're half-Japans?

Yeah, so the thing is that not only the military juntas reflect the people's opinions, people sometimes form military juntas instead, but the fact of the matter is that people want democracy over anything else in the first instance. First argument then, on why the continued presence of France in West Africa is principally unjust. The first thing is that status quo is an extension of colonialism. France continues to exploit West Africa by sucking up resources and staying inside the country. Most importantly, citizens of West Africa deeply resent France's colonial legacy. For decades, they have demanded France's exit, elected anti-French leaders, and protested outside French embassies. France's continuous dominance against their will is by definition full of illicit. But why does this principally necessitate France to exit West Africa? There are two independent reasons why France's presence is principally wrong, if either of them stands, France ought to be. Firstly, France possesses something that is not rightfully deserved. We think when France benefits heavily from things which they have unfairly gained from West Africa, that is theft. We think theft is inherently unjust, regardless of whatever benefits side opposition may want to talk about their two implications. A. Analogously, we don't take so much talent away from them because we can take care of the talent better. Given that France's mere presence in West Africa and other countries was unjustly acquired, it is only fair that they exit altogether. Note that this principal reason is not contingent on any practical outcomes. This, in and of itself, requires France to forfeit its rule because it is not deferred. The second reason is that France exiting is the best method to maximize the agency of individuals. West African countries are currently mere puppets whose strengths are controlled by France, and the best way for them to be free is to be cut those strings. France has systematically maintained a power imbalance within the citizens of West Africa for two reasons. A, massive military capabilities, political lobby to endorse specific politicians, selfless incentives to select which projects to do, uniquely makes the voting power, taxing benefits, and voices of the citizens not be heard. Therefore, the best form of reciprocal power that citizens can obtain by France exiting West Africa and then being able to channel their voting rights and political preference into actual action by deciding which local political party to stand behind. For those reasons, France must be West Africa. Moving on to the second argument then, on why we get economic development in West Africa. This comes in two layers. First layer, why the presence of France has stunted West African economic development. During the colonial era, France set up economic systems that enabled it to dominate West African countries' economies and make West African countries overly reliant on France. France has created a system that never allows for these countries to grow in any way whatsoever. After the French exit, we get economic development for two main reasons. One, though, the abolition of the CFA-Franc. There are three main problems with the CFA-Franc that still linger to this day. A. France requires a massive portion, nearly 70% of Africa's nation's reserves, to be stored in a French treasury, inaccessible to African nations. B, it instills instability, because nations cannot control their own currency. They cannot control interest rates and control inflation and stuff like that. C, the currency is tied to the Euro, which leads to extreme appreciation, and therefore decreased exports and more expensive imports. This is like when Senegal couldn't export their rice anymore because the price of them increased so much that Thai rice outcompeted them. The abolishment of the CFA franc and the shift to a more local currency can change this as they get more control over their own currency and have a currency that is more proximate to their area. Also due to mounting anti-trust sentiment in West African countries and multiple regress from West African regimes, France abolished the French Foreign Reserve Policy. This led to countries like Senegal being able to enact huge macroeconomic policies worth more than $2 billion during the COVID-19 crisis. title: WSDC 2024 R6 - Japan vs Brazil
description:
This House would introduce a governmental basic income for all artists, rather than offering governmental fellowships and grants to certain artists upon application.

Basic income for artists is a policy in which governments provide all artists with a regular, unconditional sum of money to ensure a basic standard of living, regardless of income or employment status.

Fellowships and grants are programs in which governments or organizations provide artists with financial support, often for a specific project or period of time, based on merit or need. These funds are typically awarded through a competitive application process.

3-0 Japan Wins
motion: This House would introduce a governmental basic income for all artists, rather than offering governmental fellowships and grants to certain artists upon application.

argument_units.text: Art is a source of expression, a source of happiness for artists and people. But at the same time, in the status quo, art is an inherently extremely fragile profession. Because under the status quo, when there are only grants and fellowships, art is a lucky opportunity that is only granted to the richest, most lucky individuals who manage to get through these applications.
We believe on side proposition that art should be accessible, it should be enjoyed by all individuals, including those at the bottom of the social ladder. So proud to propose.

My arguments for today is firstly on increased accessibility of art, and secondly, why fellowships hurt minorities disproportionately and why we're able to benefit those minorities on our side. But before that two pieces on framing. Firstly, what does the implementation of this basic income policy look like? We think that this basically looks like providing less than the basic income and only the basic living expenses for these people. The implication of this is that there will be no irrational opt-in from actors who don't really want to pursue art. Because this is not a huge grant. We are providing them with the basic necessities that they need to keep on living. The people who will benefit from this policy are the people in the status quo who want to pursue art. But secondly, what is the definition of artist and who are the artists who will be funding? We think that there are two criteria. Firstly, that these people will basically have to have some, be making some sort of income from art. But secondly, that they have to be making art at some level of consistency. The implication of this is that this person who just made one song like 20 years ago and has not made any songs since is simply not going to be able to continuously get money from this policy.

With that then, on to our first argument of increased accessibility on art. There are two layers to this argument. First layer, why under fellowship and grant programs in the status quo, not many people can access art in the first place. This is simply due to the fact that currently the art industry is very, very competitive, and you have to take down lots of competition in order to even get these grants in the first place, which are incredibly limited. You do not know who gets these grants, because, especially so, since in order to get a grant, you need to pass these application processes. What that means is that inherently, people who had access to money to go to art schools, who had money to access good paint brushes, good paint, who had money to be able to have the capacity to have time to even create these art pieces or create great art pieces to send to the application process. Only those rich and very privileged individuals can get access to these grants and fellowships on our side of the house. We think this is also extremely difficult for people to just balance the application process with other things like applying for your side jobs for example. So the implication of this is that poor people, especially those who need to do multiple jobs at the same time, are very very disadvantaged when it comes to applying for these applications because they cannot produce good enough quality art to be the people at the top. Note that there's also no guarantee, again, even if you as a poor person are able to get a grant the first time, there's no guarantee that you'll be able to get a grant the second time and the third time because it is so competitive. On that side, no thank you, we think that because of this, on that side, many people have to quit art in the first place because their paintings do not go through the application process and they're not even able to get out into the public sphere. We think that there are also people who pursue art because they're so passionate about art, but because they continue to pursue this, they are only depleting money from their pockets and going into the cycle of eternal poverty, not being able to get any money whatsoever. This looks like the people who create mangas in Japan. We think that there are many people who like to pursue mangas but simply cannot get enough income to sustain their basic necessities and they keep but and yet they still keep on going. On the comparative, on our side, under our policy, everyone is able to get money. Every single artist is able to get money. So on to later to them. What is the impact of this? The impact of this is twofold. Firstly, everyone who wants to pursue art can pursue art. And note that this is incredibly important, Josh, because the characterization of these artists are that these people inherently want to pursue art because you wouldn't be an artist if you didn't like doing art, right? So on that side, when we're actively taking away the opportunities to succeed, it's incredibly mentally harming and an inherent contradiction to that entire identity as an artist when we think that we are able to give them the opportunities that they deserve to be given on our side of the house. But secondly, we think that we also are able to give money to those who continue to pursue art. We think that on either side, due to passion, people will continue to pursue art. We think that we are uniquely able to give them the money and give them the basic necessities to be able to sustain themselves on our side of the house. Before I go into my second argument, what do you mean by accessing art? We think that accessing art is basically the ability for artists to be able to make profit from art, to be able to succeed from art, to be able to get self-sustainability from art.

Second argument then, why fellowships hurt minorities disproportionately. There are three mechanisms of this. Firstly, we think that in this stage, the government and the people who grant these fellowships is an amalgamation from people from majority communities, right? These people have intrinsic biases that lean towards that majority community. For example, in Japan, that would be the very rich elitist at the top. But you think that secondly, the fact that there's no objective metric to decide whether one piece of art is good or bad means that people can very easily weaponize this lack of objectivity and discriminate against minority artists. This looks like, for example, in a very white-centric community, we think that if you can have a portrait of an Asian with a portrait of a white person, even if the skills and the art style that were used were the same, we think that the white person or the portrait of the white person is more likely to be granted access and to be granted fellowship. But thirdly, we think that even if the minorities are able to get through this application process, we think that they'll still cater to the majority perspective. We think that this is because they're dependent on the majority people for that funding. What that means is that when people want to make movies about rape victims, they will not really depict the full brutality of it, and will not really blame men for it, and we think that they will downplay this to a significant extent. This also looks like whitewashed paintings of racism that exist in the state's core, and can only get publicity under that brutal policy. The implication of this is that minorities cannot get runs, and even if they do, it's only for artists who downplay their social message. So what is the importance of this? The importance of this is twofold. Firstly, on principle, we think that this is principally wrong. We think that this is an inherently arbitrary way you are born, and what status you are born, so it is wrong for the state to actively endorse discrimination against certain groups of people. Just in the same way it is not good for the state to actively fund white schools over black schools or white schools over Latino schools. We think that it is simply wrong to take this policy or to further the continuation of this policy. This policy should be for all. But secondly, we think that minority art in and of itself is extremely important, especially for those minorities, because it is simply very liberating for them to be able to express their anger, to express their oppression. We think that at the point in which the state is not allowing them to do this, we think that we should take this policy that allows minorities to at least be able to self-express themselves and make an income from it. But lastly, we think that there are many societal implications of this. The fact that literary arts like the colour purple or music from artistic choice of art spread huge societal messages to the rest of society, we think that on that side, that is at the point in which you're not able to get the societal narratives out in the open. For all those reasons, proud to propose. Thank you.
