title: WSDC 2018 R7: Estonia vs New Zealand
description:
TH regrets the Belt and Road initiative

Estonia PROP vs New Zealand OPP

3:0 New Zealand won
motion: This House regrets the Belt and Road Initiative.

argument_units.text: Now, I invite the first speaker from the side of the stage. Honourable panel, the Belt and Road Initiative is a Chinese immensely ambitious development strategy which purposes to control world trade and change the global power balance towards China. China plans to invest $900 billion into connecting the Eurasian and African countries with China through six land-based economic corridors and an ocean-going maritime support. This is done by investing into expensive infrastructure projects in other nations.

However, we have noticed that this is not a charity. For hosting nations, there are mainly two scenarios. Either the states find themselves in debt traps to the Chinese government, or if they have no hope of paying back alone, they would have to give away their infrastructure to China, ports, roads, railways, or even their territory. Both of these options are horrific, and Team Estonia is very proud to regret the Belt and Road Initiative. But let's let the filter into this Belt and Belt and Road Initiative. Most of these nations are emerging economies, and even without the Belt and Road Initiative, are experiencing economic growth and moving towards a positive direction. Ethiopia has 10% and Pakistan has 7% of GDP growth. And the same is in most of the nations that host the initiative. Now the growth means that they are fighting without Chinese investments in the long run and will likely build the same scale infrastructure with their own capital without taking loans and giving away their infrastructure just after 50 years or so. But notice that there are also other alternatives like international government banks or private capital that has always incentive to help the cheap workforce. So now our whole case for today is why the initiatives of HARP are much worse than waiting for these nations to get on their feet by themselves or with the help of other actors.

This debate is not from the perspective of China or the West, but rather this debate should be assessed from a global perspective. Today in my speech, firstly, I'm going to look at regional impacts, secondly, global impacts, and our second speaker will tell you about the risk, wealth, and road initiative. Before we move on to my first argument, do you think Donald Trump would provide better trade opportunities for Pakistan? We believe that, of course, Pakistan has other trade opportunities rather than with China. We don't believe that China is the only one who is able to provide trade opportunities for the belt and road initiative. But notice that we don't regret China doing bilateral agreements with separate states, which states have the legitimacy to control them themselves. We just regret the initiative where these individual states have very little capability of deciding for themselves.

But now, let's get into our first argument, how the initiative affects the whole situation. States care mainly about two things, their sovereignty and their economic prosperity. Here are three reasons how the host nations' economies will be damaged. Firstly, China offers predatory loans to these nations, which means the high interest rates that drain these States' budget are in place. Now, China gave Sri Lanka a low interest rate of 6.3%, while the interest rate of the World Bank and the National Development Bank were only 3% for similar loans. So the unfair loans make states directly poorer in the long run. Second way how it harms the economy is that China takes hold of their infrastructure and hence damaging them. Sri
Lanka had to hand the way the airport to the Chinese government

for a hundred years due to great debt. Look, this means that Sri Lanka has spent a lot of money on the port and has now no benefit from it at all. Furthermore, China now dictates what products flow through its ports, roads and railways, so it prioritises China's stations and current interests instead of bringing these states benefits. China is currently bringing in her manufacturing groups, while the Sri Lankan economy actually needs raw materials so desperately. China also does this in other countries like Pakistan and Kazakhstan, and the states are earning more benefit from the infrastructure that they will build, hence leading them in debt just to serve the interests of another nation. Now, the very last reason of how their economy will be damaged is that the initiative influences local markets and manufacturers very negatively. The Belt and Road Initiative makes it key to Chinese growth and more accessible in these nations, which means that these nations' own products often can't compete and local sectors and companies are pushed out of the market. Madagascar's tech side industry suffered after China's company started exporting their own product into Madagascar through the Belt and Road Initiative. So their impact is that if you come close to China, the local people are left poor and jobless, even more than they were before the initiative.

I have shown you that this is destructive to their economy,. But let's look at how it affects their sovereignty. States are dependent on China and foreign governments and this limits their own decision making. Because Chinese people already influence their inner state decisions through the immense lobbying power that they have. Chinese business people lobby for their decisions and their interests. There are more of them due to the increased business of China now with the Belt and Road Initiative. And it was also the Chinese size of other issues in foreign policy. China can now influence other nations to support its actions in the territorial disputes because they are economically dependent on China. China offered development aid to Brunei and Laos so it could support its controversial actions, militarily seizing other nations' territories and assault China's sea in order for them to get development aid. So this means that small states are afraid of lagging behind China and hence they obey. So this allows more parts of China to exercise an aggressive foreign policy that before you had an incentive to do that right now.

But now, let me move on to my second argument that describes the global impacts of China expanding their power. Military expansion is an inherent part of the Belt and Road Initiative. The reason why China is willing to execute a project that's so expensive and yet likely to fail is because it enables them to expand their power militarily. China needs to protect its economic rights and guarantee the stability on the way. So China has already said that in order to afford the Djibouti that they build to work, they need to keep their military present in order to protect it. They have already put this in Djibouti, they have brought into Pakistan 150,000 special security division to protect the road. They have plans to build military bases in Afghanistan, in Poland, and they are likely to build more bases all over the world once the initiative advances. Two very destructive impact from that when China builds these bases. Firstly, it raises tensions, and secondly, it increases the risk of a direct military conflict. Firstly, it raises tensions because political tensions and worries of other nations are very unlikely to support China's military expansion. My sons, America has over 800 military bases stationed all outside its own territory, including in Guam and South Korea. So why should America be allowed to do that and not China? Sure, I got your point. We believe that yes, the USA has already very many military bases. USA is protecting their bases in Guam, and China is likely to do that with other bases also. The more military bases next to each other with armed soldiers, the likely is a skirmish or a military accidental conflict between them. So, panel, the Belt and Road Initiative is only beneficial for China and very destructive for our little nations and also the whole world if it doesn't bring security. For all these reasons, I beg you to report. Take a deep breath. to deliver their speech. Thank you. In the aftermath of World War II, with Europe crippled by war, the United States stepped up and provided billions of infrastructure investments in a plan known as the Marshall Plan. But secondly, that these countries still get the benefits from these things. So say there was a hydropower dam that China did a debt for equity swap. Citizens in that country still get the power from that dam, even though China owns it. The third sub-point in this point about China dictating which products go to the ports, like in Madagascar, we say that this is not usually the case, such as in the Guadalajara and Pakistan, where Pakistan is able to put its own first through. But even in software, it is that Madagascar gets raw materials from China, and that's good for them as well. Their second argument is about global impacts. They told you that these countries wouldn't have much, would be aligned with China and all their foreign policy, and that's fair. But then when they told us that that raised tensions because of military bases, we think it was quite telling that in response to our point of information they supported the US global hegemony over international military alliances. We say that on the counterfactual, China will still always pursue strategic interests. It is not that by removing the Belt and Road Initiative you get rid of all the incentives for China to devalue militarily. So they don't solve that anymore. And we will prove why we do the way we actually de-escalate tensions in the South China Sea later in my hour.

First I want to know why BRI countries are better off aligning themselves with China than with the West. Recognise that these nations often find it very difficult to attract investment from the West, because the West's investment is tied purely to its geopolitical goals.
